name: doing sth to deal with a situation

children.name: to do sth to deal with a bad situation
do sth
children.definition: to do sth to deal with a problem, especially one that is urgent:
examples: Quick, do something - there’s water all over the kitchen floor.
We need to do something before everyone gets fed up and quits.

children.name: do sth about
examples: When are you going to do something about this broken window?
Teenagers were dropping out of school in huge numbers, until a group of parents and teachers decided to do something about it.

children.name: take action
children.definition: to do sth to stop a bad situation from happening or continuing - use this to talk about people who have a clear plan for dealing with a problem: hành động
examples: Unless governments take action, the Earth’s atmosphere will continue to heat up.

children.name: take action against
examples: The school will take strong action against any students using illegal drugs.

children.name: take action on
examples: Congress is expected to take action on campaign finance reform soon.

children.name: take action to do sth
examples: The President may step in and take action to lower energy prices.

children.name: act
children.definition: to use your power or authority to deal with an urgent problem: hành động
examples: The company acted correctly in sacking him.
The jury decided that Walker had acted in self-defence.
We must act before the situation gets out of control.
Despite the crisis, the Commission seems unwilling to act.
Critics accuse the company of acting too slowly in notifying residents of the chemical leak.

children.name: act to do something
examples: The UN must act now to restore democracy.
Politicians will only act when enough people demand that they do something.

children.name: Register
examples: In everyday English, people often use expressions likedo the right thingordo a brave thingrather than useactwith an adverb such ascorrectlyorbravely:
Theyacted correctlyin telling her.➔Theydid the right thingin telling her.
Whenactis used alone to mean ‘take action’, in everyday English people usually just saydo something:
We have todo somethingnow.

children.name: take steps
children.definition: /take measuresB2  if a government or sb in a position of power takes steps or measures, they do what is necessary to improve a situation or to deal with a problem: thực hiện bước, biện pháp
examples: The governor has not yet decided what measures should be taken.

children.name: take steps/take measures to do sth
examples: All departments must take measures now to reduce costs.
We apologize for the error and have taken steps to see that it does not happen again.

children.name: take drastic measures
examples: Drastic measures will be taken against those who engage in terrorism.

children.name: sth that sb does to deal with a situation
action
children.definition: the process of doing sth, especially in order to achieve a particular thing: hành động

children.name: take action
children.definition: do something to deal with a problem
examples: The government must take action to control inflation.

children.name: demand/call for action
children.definition: ask forcefully
examples: Voters are demanding tougher action on gun crime.

children.name: swing/spring/leap into action
children.definition: suddenly start doing something
examples: The fire crew immediately swung into action.

children.name: put sth into action
children.definition: start doing something you have planned to do
examples: She was looking forward to putting her plans into action.|The committee uses the expertise of local organisations to put these ideas into action.

children.name: immediate/prompt/swift action
examples: The public wants immediate action to stop the terrorists.

children.name: urgent action
children.definition: that needs to be done immediately
examples: The Opposition called for urgent action to reduce unemployment.

children.name: firm/tough action
examples: We need firm action to deal with the problem.

children.name: decisive action
children.definition: that has a big effect on the way something develops
examples: We are urging the international community to take decisive action on debt relief.

children.name: drastic action
children.definition: that has a very severe effect
examples: The President decided to take drastic action.

children.name: further action
examples: No further action is necessary.

children.name: direct action
children.definition: that is aimed at making a government or company do something
examples: In a bid to stop whale hunting, Greenpeace have threatened direct action.

children.name: political action
examples: Some forms of political action are more effective than others.

children.name: industrial/strike action
children.definition: that workers take in order to protest about pay, working conditions etc
examples: The miners voted in favour of industrial action.

children.name: joint action
children.definition: that two or more countries, organizations etc take together
examples: Community leaders agreed to take joint action on scientific, social and environmental issues.

children.name: a course of action
examples: Have you decided on a course of action?

children.name: a plan of action
examples: The General outlined his plan of action for the campaign.|Environmental groups have put forward an action plan.

children.name: action on
examples: Environmental groups want tougher action on pollution from cars.

children.name: step
children.definition: one of a series of things that someone does in order to deal with a problem or to achieve success: bước đi
examples: step in (doing) something
This is the first step in reforming the welfare system.
step to do something
The president took immediate steps to stop the fighting.
step towards
an important step towards peace

children.name: take a step
examples: The authority will take steps to reunite the child and his family.

children.name: an important/major/big step
examples: The move is seen as a major step forward for UK firms.

children.name: the first step
examples: The first step in resolving conflict is to understand what the other person wants.

children.name: the next step
examples: He met in Washington with his campaign advisers to plan his next step.

children.name: a small step
examples: This is a small step in the right direction.

children.name: a positive step
children.definition: an action that will have a good effect
examples: This is a positive step which gives cause for some optimism.

children.name: an unusual/unprecedented step
children.definition: something that is not usually done/has never been done before
examples: Police last night took the unusual step of releasing photographs of him.

children.name: a drastic step
examples: The government is wary of taking any drastic steps that would scare off foreign investment.

children.name: a bold step
examples: We welcome the bold step taken by President Bush.

children.name: a tentative step
children.definition: a small action, which is not done in a very determined way
examples: The Institute has taken a tentative step towards opening up its meetings to the public.

children.name: a logical step
examples: She felt she had an aptitude for medicine. Her next logical step would be to begin studying when the summer was over.

children.name: immediate steps
examples: We believe immediate steps could be taken to generate jobs.

children.name: reasonable steps
examples: They must take reasonable steps to ensure that this information is available to those who might benefit.

children.name: necessary steps
examples: We must be sure that we are taking the necessary steps to prevent the problem from getting a foothold here.

children.name: a step forward
children.definition: an action that makes things better
examples: The declaration which we have just signed is a big step forward for both of our nations.

children.name: a step backwards/a backward step
children.definition: an action that makes things worse
examples: A rationing system would be a major step backwards.

children.name: a step in the right direction
children.definition: an action that helps to improve things
examples: Environmentalists said the law was a step in the right direction.

children.name: measure
children.definition: an action taken by a government or someone in authority to deal with a problem or improve a situation, for example by making a new law or rule: biện pháp, phương sách
examples: Measures are being taken to reduce crime in the city.

children.name: take measures
children.definition: do something in order to deal with a problem
examples: We are taking measures to improve the situation.

children.name: adopt/introduce a measure
children.definition: start using a particular way of dealing with a problem
examples: The countries agreed to adopt measures to reduce pollution.

children.name: a measure is aimed at doing something
examples: The measures were aimed at reducing the speed of cars on the roads.

children.name: a safety measure
examples: New safety measures were implemented after the rail crash.

children.name: a security measure
children.definition: something done to keep a place safe from danger or crime
examples: Video surveillance cameras have been installed as a security measure.

children.name: a preventative/precautionary measure
children.definition: something done to prevent something bad
examples: Vaccination against disease is a sensible preventative measure.

children.name: a extreme measure
examples: The public would not be in favour of such an extreme measure.

children.name: a drastic measure
children.definition: an extreme measure
examples: Drastic measures are needed if we are to combat global warming.

children.name: a temporary measure
children.definition: something done for a limited period of time to deal with a problem
examples: The tents were used as a temporary measure to replace homes destroyed in the floods.

children.name: a necessary measure
examples: The army will take all necessary measures to protect the public.

children.name: an appropriate measure
children.definition: a measure that is suitable for a particular situation
examples: In the event of an assault, staff will need to take appropriate measures to defend themselves.

children.name: a package/series of measures
children.definition: a set of measures used to deal with something
examples: A package of road safety measures has been announced.

children.name: measure to do sth
examples: Lawmakers are searching for the best measures to strengthen Social Security.

children.name: move
children.definition: something that you decide to do in order to achieve a particular result, especially as one of a series of planned actions: động thái, nước đi
examples: sb’s move
The management have offered less money than we wanted so what’s our next move?
His first move after taking office was to appoint four communists to his cabinet.
move to do something
the Board’s recent moves to cut interest rates
The authorities havemade no moveto resolve the conflict.

children.name: make a move
examples: We made the move mainly for financial reasons.

children.name: make no move
examples: The government made no move to hold the promised elections.

children.name: welcome the move
examples: Environmentalists welcomed the move to limit the length of fishing nets.

children.name: oppose a move
examples: Union members have opposed the move.

children.name: support a move
examples: The move was supported by the government.

children.name: a move is aimed at doing something/is designed to do something
examples: The move is aimed at strengthening its business in the region.

children.name: an important move
examples: I cannot decide on such an important move on my own.

children.name: a bold/daring move
children.definition: taking a lot of courage
examples: The writers made a bold move by kiling off the main character.

children.name: a good/smart/wise move
children.definition: sensible
examples: I’m not sure it was a good move giving him the job.

children.name: the right move
examples: He hoped he had made the right move in telling his father.

children.name: an unprecedented move
children.definition: never having happened before
examples: Barcelona began the unprecedented move of shipping in drinking water.

children.name: sb’s next move
children.definition: the next thing someone does
examples: What should happen next? What’s our next move?

children.name: a bad move
examples: It was a bad move letting him come here in the first place.

children.name: a false/wrong move
children.definition: made by mistake
examples: One wrong move and the business might never recover.

children.name: the first move
examples: She waited for Michael to make the first move.

children.name: a career move
children.definition: a decision that will improve the type of job you can do
examples: It looked like a good career move, with the possibility of promotion later.

children.name: there are moves afoot to do somethingBritish English
children.definition: there are plans, especially secret ones, to do something
examples: There are moves afoot to change things.

children.name: a move in the right direction
examples: The decision seemed to be a move in the right direction.
